feed.title: Movie Review: In Darkness
feed.subtitle: Hope and humanity to be found In Darkness. This Oscar-nominated film brings us the true story of a group of Polish Jews who escaped the Nazis by hiding in the sewers of Lvov.

content.div:
Polish director Agnieszka Holland brings us the true story of a group of Second World War Jews who avoided detection by the Nazis by hiding out in the sewers under the Polish City of Lvov, now part of Ukraine. It has since been nominated for a best foreign-language film Oscar. In Darkness marks the third time Holland has been Oscar-nominated for a Holocaust-themed film. Clearly the woman knows what she's doing; the strength in In Darkness lies in how slowly and yet inexorably the sewer worker's convictions turn.

Starring: Robert Wieckiewicz, Benno Furmann and Agnieszka Grochowska

Rating: Four out of five stars

Sewer scenes can add great drama to a movie -- think of the finale of The Third Man, Andy Dufresne's escape from Shawshank prison or, for younger moviegoers, Nemo's getaway in Finding Nemo. But it takes a certain audacity to film most of your story in a dank, dark, underground location.

Polish director Agnieszka Holland had little choice once she agreed to take on this true story of a group of Second World War Jews who avoided detection by the Nazis by hiding out in the sewers under the Polish City of Lvov, now part of Ukraine. She turned down the assignment twice, mind you, until the producers agreed that the film be shot in Polish and not English. It has since been nominated for a best foreign-language film Oscar.

The story gets off to a somewhat disjointed start. Leo Socha (Robert Wieckiewicz) and his much younger colleague (Krzysztof Skonieczny) are municipal sewer workers but also small-time, opportunistic criminals; picture a rougher version of Ralph Kramden and Ed Norton from The Honeymooners. One day they hear sounds of tunnelling coming from the Nazi-enforced Jewish ghetto, and find a group of people planning an escape.

Socha, who boasts that he knows the sewers better than he does his wife, agrees to help them for a daily fee, an arrangement that gives both sides the opportunity to grumble and hurl insults at the other. To the Jews, the Catholic Socha is practically in bed with the enemy. Socha, meanwhile, is anti-Semitic by rote, which at least leaves him open to the possibility of learning to see Jews as more than a ready source of cash.

There's no shortage of atrocity to make him think twice. One early scene has him witness a group of women, naked and screaming, running through woods while being shot at by German soldiers. Later, he comes upon bodies heaped on carts, left to rot in the streets, or dumped into the sewers, which at least gives him a plausible excuse for why he's down there so often -- he has to keep the waterways free of blockages.

A movie that only followed Socha's journey would be a pretty thin composition -- though the title Schindler's Ditch could work. Thankfully, David F. Shamoon's screenplay, adapted from Robert Marshall's book In the Sewers of Lvov, gives us a rich mix of refugees, filling them out into more than mere shivering stereotypes.

Benno Furmann plays Mundek, self-appointed leader of the group. There are two sisters who are separated in the early going when one of them decides to take her chances on the surface. A philandering husband, a pregnant woman and two young siblings are also present -- there's a wonderfully telling scene in which the little girl, drawing with crayons, pauses to calmly remove a rat that has wandered onto her paper.

In the world above, filmed in blinding brightness, Socha scrambles to buy food for "his Jews" and to allay the suspicions of his overly friendly pal Bortnik, now part of the Nazi movement and eager to root out any underground stowaways and collect the bounty for them. Polish actress Kinga Preis does a fine supporting turn as Socha's understanding wife, Wanda.

In Darkness marks the third time Holland has been Oscar-nominated for a Holocaust-themed film. 1985's Angry Harvest was similarly nominated for best foreign language film, while 1990's Europa Europa picked up a best screenplay nod. Clearly the woman knows what she's doing; the strength in In Darkness lies in how slowly and yet inexorably the sewer worker's convictions turn.

Socha argues at one point that the profit he is making from hiding the Jews is an ethical necessity. And at some later point he clearly comes to believe that the act itself represents a kind of categorical imperative. There may even be a period where he holds both views simultaneously. The conversion, invisible even as it happens before our eyes, is nevertheless a thing to behold.
